Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies



Buena Park Cold Storage is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only a trained, licensed refrigeration contractor is permitted to perform system operations.  Buena Park Cold Storage has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



Buena Park Cold Storage is located at 6880 Caballero Blvd. in Buena Park, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage of various food products.  The system uses a maximum of 18,000 pounds of ammonia.  The process description is presented below:  



Liquid ammonia in the pilot receiver is fed to the two recirculators.  The recirculators pump liquid to the evaporators.  At the evaporators, air is drawn over the coils by the evaporator fans.  The ammonia flowing inside the coils is partially vaporized as it absorbs heat from the surrounding air.  The partially vaporized ammonia is returned to the recirculator, where the liquid settles at the bottom of the vessel, while the vapor rises to the top.  The vapor in the recirculators is pulled off by the compressors and discharged to the condenser and evaporators for defrost.  At the condenser, the vapor is condensed back into liquid, which then drains to the pilot receiver to be re-used in the refri

geration cycle.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



Buena Park Cold Storage has developed an accidental release prevention program for compliance with the OES CalARP regulations.  The program includes but is not limited to the following elements:



?    Safety information regarding the chemical hazards, and operating and technical specifications for the equipment;

?    Written procedures for operating and maintaining the processes;

?    Training for personnel involved with system operations and maintenance;

?    Investigating releases and near misses and implementing measures to prevent recurrence; and

?    Audit procedures for ensuring that the programs are being implemented in accordance to the regulations. 



In addition, engineering controls have been implemented to reduce the chance of an accidental release to the environment.  These are comprised of equipment monitoring systems and safety cutouts to shut off the equipment when operating parameters exceed safe operating limits.  Relief valves on pressurized ammonia vessels prevent equipment rupture in the event of overpressurization.  Regular inspections and tests are performed to ensure these controls are in good working order.



Five Year Accident History



A review of the facility's five year accident history showed that there have been no incidents at the facility that meet the RMP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  In addition, there have been no incidents at the facility in the last five years that resulted in a release of more than the Federal Reportable Quantity (100 pounds).
